channel.title: Home on The PC² CCS
channel.description: Recent content in Home on The PC² CCS

item.title: Current Downloads
item.description: Latest stable release: the main public release. This release has been widely used around the world in many contests and is recommended for those who want the assurances of a stable, vetted system for running their contest. Release Candidate: an advance look at the proposed next public release of PC². This release contains significant new features planned for upcoming public release. This release has been thoroughly tested, but is not yet guaranteed "

item.title: Previous Stable Downloads
item.description: NOTICE These are provided to read old DBs of said versions, we strongly recommend that you use the latest stable release from the Current Downloads page. Version 9.6.0-5102     (build date 03:34:47 on 02 January 2019) PC² System pc2-9.6.0-5102.zip (22.52 MB) (sha256, sha512) PC² System in tar.gz form pc2-9.6.0-5102.tar.gz (21.9 MB) (sha256, sha512) PC² API Documentation api-doc-9.6.0-5102.zip (0.29 MB) Version 9.5.4-4663     (build date 04:39:38 on 26 September 2018) PC² System pc2-9.

item.title: All builds
item.description: Below you will find all the available builds for the PC² CCS. Most builds also have a .sha256 and .sha512 file, which can be used to validate the downloads. Version 9.8build-6434     (build date 17:37:48 on 03 December 2022) PC² System pc2-9.8build-6434.develop.zip (58.08 MB) (sha256, sha512) PC² System in tar.gz form pc2-9.8build-6434.develop.tar.gz (88.39 MB) (sha256, sha512) PC² API Documentation api-doc-9.8build-6434.develop.zip (0.31 MB) Version 9.8build-6430     (build date 08:25:38 on 30 November 2022) PC² System pc2-9.

item.title: A Bit of History
item.description: This page could be titled “PC² – the Early Years”. It covers some (certainly not all) of what happened during the first two decades of PC² development… 1988 September: Mary Richmond, Dave Bosley, Paul Meyers, and some other guy named Doug Lane make the mistake of accepting a Senior Project called PC² from Professor John Clevenger in the Computer Science Department at CSUS. That Lane guy still has no clue. Bliss is ignorance.

item.title: Permission
item.description: The legal use of PC² is governed by the Eclipse Public License v2.0. Having said the above, it should be noted that PC² was originally developed, and continues to be developed, by a community of volunteers according to a certain set of community principles and guidelines. One of those principles centers around the concept that we didn’t develop it to make money, but rather to provide useful tools for people who want to run programming contests.
